wikitext.*:
The '''Ettendales''' were the valleys ([[Wikipedia:Dale (landform)|dales]]) of the [[Ettenmoors]] that extended up into the foothills of the [[Misty Mountains]].<ref>{{HM|UI}}, entry ''Ettendales'', p. 188</ref> They were located far north of [[Rivendell]]<ref name="Flight">{{FR|Flight}}, p. 203</ref> on the western side of the Misty Mountains near the source of the river [[Hoarwell]]<ref>[[Wayne G. Hammond]] & [[Christina Scull]], [[The Art of The Lord of the Rings]], HarperCollins, 2015, Fig. 159. Map of the northern part of Middle-earth, map square I-5 with the pencilled name ''Ettendales'' (just below ''Ettenmoors''), p. 202.</ref> and were inhabited by [[Trolls]]<ref name="Flight"/>.

==History==
In the morning of [[17 October]], {{TA|3018}},<ref>{{HM|RC}}, p. 187</ref> in [[Rhudaur]] in their camp on a stony shelf with a rock-wall behind them [[Aragorn|Strider]] told [[Frodo Baggins|Frodo]], [[Samwise Gamgee|Sam]], [[Meriadoc Brandybuck|Merry]] and [[Peregrin Took|Pippin]] that they had went too far to the north and needed to find a way back to the south. He mentioned that if they continued in the same direction, they would get up into the Ettendales far north of Rivendell. Strider said that the Ettendales were troll-country and little-known to him.<ref name="Flight"/>

==Etymology==
''Ettendales'' is a [[Westron|Common Speech]] name. It contains the obsolete element ''[[Wiktionary:ettin|eten]]'' ('troll, [[Ogres|ogre]]')" from [[Old English]] ''eoten'', which exists in English dialect as ''eten''.<ref>{{HM|N}}, entry '''Ettendales''', p. 770</ref> The second element is ''dale'' from Old English ''dael'' ("valley").<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dale_(landform)|articlename=Dale (landform)|website=en.wikipedia.org|accessed=04 March 2022}}</ref>

For more, see [[Etten#Etymology]].
